There are a number of mechanisms that could be used for this 
but you would have to check on the validity of these 
mechanisms under your particular operating conditions.  

One that I know has been used for the Partial Oxidation of 
Methane (under highly dilute operating conditions, > 80% N2) 
is the Konnov version 0.5 methane mechanism.  This mechanism 
is somewhat elaborate and may require significant 
computational time.  However, I know of at least one 
presentation and one paper that has done modeling along with 
experimental validation of this mechanism under isothermal 
conditions and with some varying stoichiometries.  However, 
you would need to check out the range where validation has 
occurred (temperature, stoichiometry, and perhaps pressure) 
to ensure that this mechanism will provide any meaningful 
quantitative results.  Also, Dr. Konnov is very helpful if 
you have any questions about this mechanism.

One note to all of these searching for mechanisms that are 
on the web, I would suggest a search using "Chemkin {Fuel} 
Mechanism" where {fuel} is the fuel you are wanting a 
mechanism and appropriate thermodynamic and transport data 
for or some similar context as that listed above.  

There are many different mechanisms that are available 
and some even provide a reference list that can be used to 
search down the appropriate bibliographic information (which 
is very handy when trying to determine which range of 
conditions the mechanisms has been validated under and also 
where reaction rate information was taken from).

For example a couple of mechanisms that can be found 
on the web are from the University of Leeds [methane], the 
Gas Research Institute (GRI Mechanisms)[methane], work by 
Charles Westbrook and coworkers at LLNL [multiple fuels 
ranging from methane to n-heptane if I recall correctly], 
and on the Berkeley website [comprehensive and reduced 
methane mechanism]. There are undoubtedly more but this 
should give everyone a good starting point.  

Sincerely,

Brad Lemke
University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
